utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And she inferred that he's committed a crime.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: OK. Can I just add something really quickly? Because everyone is talking about the I-word, impeachment, and Nancy Pelosi is the one who's most adverse to it. She's the one who doesn't want to go down that path because she says it's too divisive, but then she uses the word intervention which is like diet impeachment. It's like -- if you want to impeach him, just impeach him. Go ahead and do it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think she revealed the true agenda. She -- when she said cover up, that's what started it all. The president is engaged in a cover-up. Then she went into the infrastructure meeting. It was clear that what she was -- what -- inadvertently she reveal was the Speaker of the House is with the radical Democrats that she wants impeachment. It's just a question of tactically when to launch the A-bomb.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right after that and said impeachment is certainly something maybe we should do right after she accused him of a cover-up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But it is another lesson for American viewers about the media and how the -- with the direction the media takes. Who do they mimic? Who do they champion? You go back to the attacks on Kavanaugh, as a mob. At the elevation of Smollett. The elevation of Avenatti. Now Pelosi is kind of like their Avenatti. It's like they switch out one Trump-killer for another Trump-killer, because this Trump-killer didn't work, right? So Pelosi is going to be the one -- she should run, actually, but -- Avenatti, Smollett, none of this stuff is working so they have to keep trying new ones.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Avenatti, Smollett, and then the Speaker of the House of Representatives, that's your trio? I know where your head is at --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: But what about Jerry Nadler, it's the same thing. Like they invest -- and Greg is right about that, they invest hopes in a new titan, pretty much quarterly. It's a new person that they're hoping that they will have the magical combination for the Rubik's cube that will be the president's undoing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And today, Jerry Nadler, I believe, fainted at a public event, lost consciousness, had to be resuscitated --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No joke.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- by the mayor here. He had a glass of water and I think he's feeling better. So we just want to let the audience know that Jerry Nadler is doing --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Can we talk about the media again doing their own self-diagnosis of the problem? Like, you're not allowed to make any jokes right now about Jerry Nadler having an issue, but people like Joe Scarborough are allowed to go on national television and say that people have told him without actually naming anybody, that people have told him that the president is pre-dementia. I remember when it's not allowed -- we weren't allowed to ask about anybody's health when it came to that, but now news anchors are diagnosing people's mental health.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: And if you have said that about Hillary Clinton --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, not allowed.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But with Nadler it looked like, you know, because he used to be a lot larger, I've known him forever, and now he's deflated, you know, people lose a lot of weight, they look like they -- and he looked awful. But Republicans are fortunate that the two most unattractive people in Washington, Adam Schiff and Jerry Nadler, are the point people for the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Basically on a track, they are.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want -- the point about accusing somebody or suggesting that the leader of the free world has dementia, you're kind of suggesting that he needs to be removed by any means necessary --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Treason.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- because a hero -- if he's demented, a hero would remove him. I mean, there're some dangerous, you know, conclusions you can draw from that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Seriously speaking in this Barr investigation, let's see where that leads. How close did they come to the 25th amendment B.S.? How close did they come for this latent coup happening, you know, as they were, you know, plotting, OK, what do we do now with these --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because we already know that Andy McCabe opened up an obstruction investigation into the president the day after he fired James Comey.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They've just gone from -- they're gone on this list of things that they couldn't defeat Trump on, whether it was the election, the special counsel investigation, now they're trying to do impeachment without doing impeachment --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And now they're back to mentally ill.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- the media, the DNC list server, apparently went around with everyone using the same kind of terminology, and now they're saying he may have dementia as Greg said. Well, there's a solution to that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: If you really want to do the right thing for the country and that's to remove him from office.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I saw that movie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Coming up, President Trump's major move to declassify Russia probe documents, up next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: President Trump announcing a major move to investigate the investigators. He's giving Attorney General Bill Barr the authority to declassify any documents related to the Russia probe. The president hitting Democrats and explaining the decision.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: They want to try and get a do-over of the Mueller report. It doesn't work that way. I declassified, I guess, potentially millions of pages of documents. I don't know what it is. I have no idea. But I want to be transparent. Our attorney general is in charge. Let's see what he finds.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Congressman Adam Schiff ripping the move saying, quote, the cover-up has entered a new and dangerous phrase and also it's un-American. So, Jesse, now that this declassification of millions of documents has occurred, do you think that this deep state is going to fight back because you have to work with a bunch of different agencies who were allegedly involved?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, all the scoundrels involved in the coup attempt are gone. If you think about Comey, McCabe, Strzok, Page, all those gangsters are now out of there, so you can't really do much.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There's the FBI, though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: True, and I'm sure there's some other bad players out there. But if you declassify everything you're going to have access to raw source documents, the FISA applications and the 302's, and this is why the media is so upset by this. It's the first time Donald Trump has convinced the media to be against transparency. The media does not want to see secret CIA and FBI documents for the very first time. Usually, they win Pulitzer Prize, you know, finding these documents from the Vietnam War until now. Now they don't want to see it because they know they participated in a witch-hunt. They know that all of their heroes like Comey have been lying. And like Greg said, Comey is the new Avenatti. They're going to dump him as soon as the crosshairs go over his head. It's curtains for this guy. You better lawyer up.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Greg --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's even worse than that because -- remember, there was two parts to Mueller. There's collusion and there's obstruction. So if there's no collusion, how do you obstruct no crime? It's not an obstruction of justice --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Juan, you're making so much sense.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Obstruction of injustice. It really is. Obstruction of injustice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. That was my line, you stole that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I had it first.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I invented -- I remember the eureka moment, it came to me. But I mean, imagine when you see that Mueller knew in March or June of 2017 that there was no collusion and didn't tell the president. So he kept the investigation going making Trump crazy, so he's making Trump fire that one, fire that one. So why didn't he tell the president there was no collusion? Because he was setting a perjury trap for the President of the United States. I think that these documents will be extremely unsettling for the people that have been promoting the whole notion of a Russian --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They've totally moved the goal post because they accused the president of obstruction when it came to the Mueller investigation. And now they're saying, well, he's obstructing justice by not complying with the subpoenas that Jerry Nadler is issuing to them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Could you imagine if this is how they're reacting after the Mueller report cleared the president if it had gone the other way. I mean, if this is how they're acting when the president is cleared imagine if there was something there, I mean, there would have been mobs and pitchforks. This entire circus is due to the fact that the media and the Democrats got their asses handed to them in 2016. And then again with Mueller -- Mueller was a repeat of the election and I'm saying that as somebody who didn't vote for Trump but grew up. When the moment -- he's inaugurated -- he's my president. I didn't sit there --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Who did you vote for?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I vote -- I think I wrote in myself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Either that or crowd handler, I can't remember. But -- the thing is, after the inauguration, Trump became my president and I judged him on deeds and not words, and I've been very happy. But we're learning now the three years didn't matter, the two years didn't matter, they're going to do this to him anyway. It's -- I don't think it's about Trump. It's about our viewers. Trump is merely a proxy for the American people that the media hates. That Trump represents flyover country, non-Hollywood, non- Manhattan people who just sit there with their fingers up their noses, you know, getting drunk in their trailer park. That's the way they see it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Kennedy, what is the political benefit for Democrats here? Obviously, they're trying to satisfy their base who wants the president impeached, but the rest of the country, polling overwhelming shows that they want everyone to move on and actually focus on --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I mean, that's the problem, and Jesse kind of alluded to this is the press is going to have to do some real work here. And they're going to have to sift through these things and figure out what the worst parts were of these abuses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But how are they going to spin it?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: That's the problem, you can't spin it --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's why it's harder for them.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's problematic if this is the structure and the system that we've got, and that has to change. And, you know, you have to apply a much more objective lens to this problem because right now it's so incredibly subjective and people feel as though their opinions are facts.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think it's going to rock the FISA court. I think --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Well, that's OK. I mean, that's good. And I think --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: -- we haven't seen inside the FISA court enough. And it's not --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Probably true.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: -- I don't think that the attorney general should abstract things conveniently for the president. I think we should see much more documentation, see how these applications are rubber stamped. See how the judges justify some of those decisions. See if there's any follow through. And if it's not enough, then Congress has to get up off their booties and do something about it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Greg, I want to go back to the narrative here before we go, with the media and Democrats in Congress who are now -- Adam Schiff included, accusing the president of using law enforcement as a political weapon now as a result of declassifying this information. So they're essentially projecting what they've been doing for the last two, three, four years on to the president for being more transparent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're the only ones that are allowed to weaponized the intelligence agencies, not the president.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And also, they're also the only people who can doctor videos. The media can provide misleading editorial, but nobody else can. We can do it, but you can't.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But the thing is, right now -- I mean, there's two things going on right now. There's Trump and there's Brexit, and both of them are telling everybody the same story that the political class is suffering a global reversal.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I've got a milk shake here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well said, Steve Hilton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I knew you're going to say that.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: We've been lied to.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He said global reversal, tonight -- what his show called?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Next Revolution.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Next Revolution with Steve Hilton.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Speaking of hoaxes and the media falling for them, Jussie Smollett bragging about being innocent in the hate crime hoax could be coming back to haunt him. Find out why, up next.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: New developments in the Jussie Smollett saga, a Chicago judge ordering the disgraced actor's criminal case file unsealed, this coming nearly two months after the Cook County prosecutor suddenly dropped 16 felony counts against the Empire actor for allegedly staging a hate crime against himself. The judge saying that since Smollett has spoken to the media about his case, he has waved his right to privacy and here's an example.

utterances.speaker: JUSSIE SMOLLETT, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: I've been truthful and consistent on every single level since day one. I would not be my mother's son if I was capable of one drop of what I've been accused of.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Oh, don't you hate when the sanctimonious narcissist invoke their love for their moms. And the Chicago cops saying they plan to release Smollett's files next week. So, Katie, this is the week of the revelation. This is the week of the unsealing of the files. This is the week -- so what do you expect will happen in the city of Chicago where the prosecutor dropped this case so suddenly after getting a call from the former chief- of-staff of Michelle Obama, the most famous of Chicago residents.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, in terms of legal consequences there won't be any for Jussie Smollett, but there may be some accountability for --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I'm not so sure of that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, OK. I'll let you take that, but since the charges have been dropped, I don't know what else they could now charge with him, considering he filed a false police report and blah, blah, blah. We'll find out all the details --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, perjury.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But the point is the reason they're releasing this is because he is talking about it publicly and the public has a right to know. There're public resources used to investigate this case. He's talking about it clearly on national television. His attorneys have gone on national television and smeared the brothers that he hired and accused them of doing things like dressing up in white face and that's why Jussie was confused about who attacked him. And so, you know, this is something that he's been privileged with since the beginning, and he was privileged to have the case sealed, and I'm glad the judge is doing the right thing by holding him accountable for his actions. If he didn't want -- if he really wanted this to go away he should have kept his mouth shut.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know, Greg, I think that when you considered the fact that Empire, the show, is being canceled --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- six season, and there is no doubt in my mind but -- that this scandal helped accelerate that cancellation process. And yet, the actors in Empire stick by this guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Some of them do. You know, it's a real tragedy because I never had a chance to watch the show. Maybe it will end up somewhere else. You know, I have to hand it to them, quite a disappearing act. TMZ can't even find this guy. I have a theory, he's actually hanging out in MAGA country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Two lessons -- two lessons from the Smollett thing. Number one, he showed, like Avenatti did, how easy it is to punk the media, all you've got to do is tick all the boxes. Number one, hate Trump, right? He did that, embrace identity politics, and have an envious victim status. What he did, he created a story and the bow was the red Trump hat. The second lesson, if a story is pushed by the media that makes you angry, doubt it. Like every story in the last year that has pissed you off, made you upset, is never what it is. If you look, again, Kavanaugh, Covington, Avenatti's crap, Smollett, every -- that's what -- these were angry divisive stories pushed by the media and then they fell apart. They cheated you of your time and your energy --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And there's no follow-up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's no follow-up.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There's no follow-up to say we really, really screwed up and we're sorry for it. In fact, there's a justification for things like Michael Avenatti.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And yet, Kennedy, you have a situation here where there was an intervention. I mean, there was a political intervention. There's a special prosecutor now, you know, investigating the -- what's her name, Fox, the -- the prosecutor, Cook County prosecutor, dropping the case so suddenly. There are real-life implications, and yet he still commands, you know, some loyalty. I just don't get it. I don't see why -- I mean, to invoke a hate crime in Chicago, the city of Emmett Till, you know, that's where the kid came from who was so infamously lynched after flirting with a white girl on a trip down South. It's - these are real this, is a big to me. This guy is deserving of no sympathy and he should have really gotten - -

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And that's why the Chief of Police was so personally offended by some of Jussie Smollett's actions and he said that they were very obvious and very provable. And the worry in this country is there are two forms of justice, sometimes it's based on race and sometimes it's based on privilege and whether or not you have money. And Jussie Smollett not only had money and prestige, but he also had political access, and that's very unfair. And then Kim Foxx tried to cover her tracks by putting out that memo, saying, "OK. Is there any time where we've dropped charges in a case kind of similar to this, so they don't look like total idiots". At the same time she was supposed to have recused herself. And if you remember her spokesperson said, well she only colloquial recused herself, she didn't normally recuse herself as if--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Colloquial recusal. I didn't learn that--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's my band name.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And also I've always thought it was strange that the judge sealed the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's coming on seal now. By June 3rd it will be on seal. But Jesse listen to this, during the time the two dozen detectives were investigating - according to our brain room, there were 18 murders in Chicago, there were 104 criminal sexual assaults, 370 robberies, 423 aggravated batteries, 535 burglaries, 3401 thefts. I mean, these are all things they could have been probing instead of wasting their time chasing a fraudulent story.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, you could argue that he has blood on his hands as--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You could argue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: --a result of him tying up the police department. You could argue after two years of this country chasing around a fake story about Russia, what else could we have done then? It's such a wasted opportunity. But I tend to look at the bright side here. This man has united this country. He has brought together Fox News, Rahm Emanuel, Donald Trump and Charles Barkley, all of them say this guy's a fraud, and I think that's a good thing. Because if you look at what he--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And me. And if you look at what he wanted, he didn't get anything. He wanted a raise, didn't get it. He wanted the show to keep going, he didn't get it. He wanted the attention from the black community. Black community dropped him like a rock. This guy is toast. He should have kept that sweetheart deal and shut his mouth, but he had bad management and he's a delusional con artist, Russia hoax artists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Good - nice little follow-up there with the Russia thing.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Maybe he's Russian.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, but you know what he could redeem himself if he actually opened himself to those he despised. If he said, "OK, this was a lie, I'm going to go into MAGA country and I'm going to face the people I ridiculed".

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: How silly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, if you look at - I'm talking about to redemption--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He needs to go on the GG Show, do a full hour .

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: We ought to do what Aaron Rodgers did, get in a beer chugging contest. There's also a crazy plane moment we'll be bringing you and much more. The Fastest 7, up next.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Here we go first up. There is a reason why you never want to get into a beer chugging contest with an NFL lineman. Green Bay Packers' offensive tackle David Bakhtiari showing off his impressive skills, pounding down not one, not two cold brews at last night's NBA playoff game. But when he challenges teammate Aaron Rodgers to do the same, the star quarterback fumbles by not quite finishing his entire cup.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Party foul.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly Katie. Oh, I just got a pinkies up, just a little sip of the brews. It is a pale ale.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Embarrassed about this every Green Bay Packers fan in Wisconsin, because there is the state drain and if he can--

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Look at Bakhtiari.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Katie, I would argue that his girlfriend sitting next to him was pretty embarrassed. She didn't look very thrilled when he couldn't finish it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, she's like, "You're from Wisconsin, get it done".

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I disagree. I would - I never understood why drinking fast is a badge of honor. Like good drinkers drink slow, so you can drink the rest of your life. The guys in reputation for pounding beers--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's Miller Lite.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Its Miller Lite.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. It's not alcohol.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's not the fancy whiskey.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They have big bellies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But like the people that you grew up with that were known for pounding beer, what are they doing now?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're on “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And their bellies are hanging out over the table. He is a scotch--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: What are you--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think he's one of the most pleasant people in public life in America.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: That's how anyone who plays football--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I like him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, are you looking for tickets?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No I just like the guy. So he can't drink beer--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's like saying you have nice lawyer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: One has to make fun of them one time, is everything else he's better at.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: He's really good at.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: That's true. Much more athletic than--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And he even died in Game of Thrones.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's sad, didn't even make it to the finale.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I haven't seen the last on episode.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, stop it. Everybody dies.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: They didn't only die. They all choke on plastic water bottles, very fast.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And straws.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: All right. Up next, this guy may be the worst airline passenger in the last 30 years. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You cannot smoke on airplanes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: That's against the law. You do know that, right?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Oh, my god. Oh, my god.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: What else has he got?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That is a stoner.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Smoker was eventually escorted off the plane by police. Geraldo, you'll remember this. Maybe you're the only person here who flew when people actually smoked on planes. Remember like the last five rows were reserved for people--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Yes, Air France in first class had three rows. The first row was non-smoking, the two rows behind that were smoking.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That makes a big difference.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No, this guy is obviously vaping. He is obviously a stoner. He is wasted. He didn't know where he is. He did know what he did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think will probably woke up from the comma from the 60s. Isn't he, he's like--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: He said where is Geraldo?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is illegal. He's like Trump's President?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Trump's President, oh, sure. Sure Trump is President. Yes, right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Two possibilities, one he is on some kind of oxy, because he's definitely out of it and I don't think that's pot. But he might have seen the movie Sexy Beast. Do you remember how a Ben Kingsley gets off the plane? He smokes a cigarette, because he wants to avoid what's happening when he lands. This guy didn't - maybe didn't want to see his in-laws. So he thought I'll get arrested when I land.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But it probably oxy now you mentioned.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: He seems to have that wherewithal. But it just goes to show how much society has changed, because people used to smoke on planes. And now if you smoke on the plane, they arrest you. Everyone freaks out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He really needed that cigarette.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The last plane I was on cross country. It was a guy sitting next to me like that and he was eating marijuana and he had this little bag and got - he need to get it. You could smell it and he's like put it away. And then be like - open it again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So you were travelling with Kilmeade?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So I had somewhat of a similar experience, but I didn't report him, because I don't want to land the plane early, I had somewhere to go.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Because they would make you land it. That's it. Bring this down. And finally, a new study says people who prefer instrumental music, just like this, are much smarter. Researchers at Oxford have found there's a link between brain power and music without lyrics like jazz, classical and electronica. Take five, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It sounds to me like they want people to live in elevators. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: No, because researchers probably listened to this music, they found a way to justify their own--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think that - Jazz --- I like Jazz, but Jazz is--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. #1, part of this study is tainted by the fact that classical music fans tend to be smart. We know that because we've seen that in movies - smart people. But the other thing too is, you can think when you're listening to instrumentals. You cannot think about - you can't think your own thoughts when you have lyrics, because the lyrics actually replace your thoughts. That's why so many idiots listen to bad music, because you're influenced by like Maroon 5. When if you listen to electronica, you can actually work, that's why I really think that lyrics are dangerous to young people.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Do you hum this along?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't hum to anything.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: --all the lyrics.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You hum--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I stopped listening to the lyrics like 10 years ago, 15 years ago and my life has improved immeasurably.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, we have mouth trumpet Monday (ph) on my show.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Oh, he did?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like that. See, as you guys know, I'm a classically trained flute player and I've played for 10 years. So I think this study makes total sense. High intellectual firepower--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Did your mom get you into that?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Is that real news are fake news?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No that is real. I have pictures I will prove it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We will declassify the flute pictures.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Next Friday, we're going to publish the photos.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: All right, Fan Mail Friday is next. You are the luckiest person in the world. Stay here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Fan Mail Friday. That's true Geraldo. Let's get to your questions. First one from Phil. Hey, Phil how are you? Good, Greg. "What was your most memorable experience with law enforcement?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who said oh, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Katie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Katie?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've been arrested. Is there a mug shot?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, I am never been arrested.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. But why did you say, "Oh, no". Go - say, what's in your head right now.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Because one time as a teenager I ran from the police, because I was drinking.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's - everybody does that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I got stopped going 105 and 107, by the by CHIPS California Highway Patrol and he came really aggressively to my window and--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Then he recognized you.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Saw it was me and started laughing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I got pulled over by a cop and I thought I was speeding, but he just wanted a picture with me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, he didn't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Swear to god. It was Michigan.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I don't believe that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do not say who he is, he's going to lose his job and his family and his friends.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's awful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's awful. That's a horrible story.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I was--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: --pulling over Jesse Watters so he can get a picture with him? I mean, it sound like you're Danny--

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: That's illegal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think it is illegal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Go ahead Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: No, I was lucky enough to do a ride-along with my brother when he was a member of the Gresham Police Department in Gresham, Oregon and I wore all black and they gave me a Kevlar vest and I had combat boots and I pretended like I was going--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Am I the only one who didn't admit it anything?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, I was underage drinking, and the police pulled up. This is in front of QFI in El Camino, San Mateo and I hid behind a bush, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A little bush.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A little bush. And the convoy - it was a big bush and the cops yelled for me - yelled to come out and I when I walked outside I had scared the police officer, because I came out from behind a bush--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Lucky, he didn't shoot you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what he said to me. He said you're lucky I didn't shoot you, because I saw you cut - I didn't know - I thought you were over there. And then they let me go.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Greg.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: For helping me out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, I've got worse ones.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK. Good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Richard asks, this is a trend, "Tell us about your first hospital experience" - stitches, broken, bone, etc - that's short for et cetera. Kennedy, first hospital experience?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I was thrown into a TV set when I was three years old - four years old by a neighbor Blair Brasilia (ph) He picked me up, threw me in from the TV and that was my first concussion.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: So I rode to the hospital in an ambulance and woke up speaking Latin.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I fractured my wrist falling off a seesaw at two.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: At two.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I've had a lot --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I have scars - punch walls--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Punched the walls--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It was actually a window--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sounds like you were chugging beer before--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I was, being Aaron Rogers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I was born in a hospital.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, I went to the hospital and - I couldn't breathe and I was there for two days.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You couldn't breathe.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's real bad. I had asthma as a kid.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And you remember--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes. It's over now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, nerds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I had high school strong pot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's the best story.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You were like wandering around.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, it's like every - it's every - almost one in every four kids ends up at the emergency room thinking they were going to die because they smoked weed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm one of those kids.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Only you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I thought I was going to die and the cops were just laughing at me. One of them put a flashlight, "you're okay, just go home, drink some hot chocolate". My parents were like just like shaking their heads. All right. In 40 year - oh, great question, "In 40 years what will people be nostalgic for?" Interesting.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Nothing.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think probably Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Somebody is getting tweeted tonight. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Nostalgic for?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Real pets and real people, because everything's going to be robots.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I was going to say pre cell phone - before cell phones.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's like now --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I mean --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Remember the 90s we had no phones.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's - you're already nostalgic for that. What's now?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: In 40 years.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now that you would be - you know it's not going to be here, but you're going to miss THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: THE FIVE. I'm not going to be around in a couple of years?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, 40 years.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg - longevity man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Your head will be in a vat - a nutrient vats. It'll be five brains.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Oh people would be nostalgic for big butts. They are very --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You think people are getting slimmer is that your --?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: No, I think right now people have like big, injected - like there are classes to make your butts --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Biometrics, it's over it's all the gym classes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: --bar and SOT (ph) and all that stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm going to say driving and drivers, because that's - that will be the thing that's gone. It'll all be self-driving. And we'll--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Everybody loves to drive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, but people are going to - you mean other humans drove for you.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think the investment in driverless cars is going to be a big, big, empty--

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, we got to go. "One More Thing", up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing". So guys following this crazy guy on Jeopardy!, he's almost crossed $2 million - really, really close call. He was down by about $13,000 last night in the second round. He almost - well, just watch what happened.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: And you add 10,000, putting you in the lead with 35,800, so champ over to you now. Are you taking the a-train? Are you taking the a- train to victory? Oh, yes you are 20,908 (ph). Yes, you can breathe the sigh of relief.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There he is, and look at him. Here gets a little cocky, throws out the Jordan tongue wag. Kind of a weird thing to do, but big game James can do it every once there. He is licking his chops.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Didn't they just - didn't we already show what he won before he show that?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: What is he Miley Cyrus?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think it was producer. Also speaking of appropriate "Watters World" - Lindsey Graham making his "Watters World" debut Saturday at 8:00 o'clock.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A Graham cracker.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There is Greg Gutfeld is next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. My show. Tomorrow night 10:00 p.m. I got the great writer Walter Kirn; we got Dr. Drew Pinsky, he's going to solve a lot of my problems, there are plenty. And of course, Kat Timpf, and Tyrus both have two new shows on Fox Nation which you got to check out. Now it's time for Greg's How About These Ducks! This is a new segment on Fox will be on every single day for the next 10 years. Check out my ducks. Look at all these ducks.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Those are ducks, Jesse crossing the street. This is in a country that I forgot. But imagine some country, I think it might be it might be Thailand or - but anyway the ducks are crossing the street as you can tell. And now I'm going to shut up.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Why does a duck cross the road?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Why these - Thailand.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You made that up?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I did. I was a foul comment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Excellent. All right, Kennedy?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: This is such a great story. From Gaylord Focker or actually from Will Hunting to Gaylord Focker. A young man who was a janitor at NYU's Tisch Langone Hospital, he was a janitor there when he was 17 years old, now he's 29. He just graduated Sigma Theta Tau, the international Honor Society of nursing. From the same hospital where he was a janitor, he is now a decorated nurse and he goes into the nursing program there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A man nurse.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes - Gaylord Focker.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Got the reference.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: From one can to another.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Congratulations. Geraldo?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Long time ago I exposed the conditions in a dreadful institution for the population we used to describe as mentally retarded. Now we call these folks who are disabled - developmentally disabled, some are artistic. We got them out of the institutions in nice community-based residences.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: One of the many agencies - a great one that does these community- based residences Life's WORC. We raise funds, we use to box. John Lennon did a concert for me. Now we do the golf tournament. It's a next Thursday May 30th, is the 32nd edition of the golf tournament. We've raised about $7 million with these golf tournaments to create these homes that really are wonderful humane, progressive places where their potential is realized.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Beautiful, awesome.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What clubs they are?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: What club do we play at?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, we play at various clubs around. The organization is--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm available next Thursday. I mean--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, come on by. Hannity comes for--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Memorial Day is on Monday and the Poppy Wall of Honor--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: We need to remember what Memorial Day is all about - has returned to the National Mall for the second consecutive year to honored more than 645,000 American service members who gave their lives to our nation since World War I. Yesterday, the U.S. Army old guard put a bunch of flags at Arlington Cemetery to remember the sacrifices that have been made there. So, happy Memorial Day and I know that we are all grateful for the service of people who have given the ultimate sacrifice for us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we are. All right. We'll see you back here on Monday for our Memorial Day special. Don't miss it. Have a great Memorial Day weekend.
